documentType: Bureau of Prisons incident report and memoranda
summary: This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons forms and memoranda detailing the discovery, medical response, and aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019. It includes the initial incident report, staff accounts of the response, and notes on the transport of his body to the hospital and morgue.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019, and later pronounced deceased. The documents detail the medical emergency response and his subsequent death.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at approximately 6:33 a.m. Staff performed CPR and he was transported to the hospital, where he was pronounced deceased at 7:36 a.m. The incident is classified as a suicide.

events.title: Body Transport to Morgue
events.description: Epstein's remains were prepared at the hospital and transported by the Office of City Medical Examiner (OCME) staff to the city morgue at approximately 12:57 p.m.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, 150 Park Row, New York, NY (Main Facility, SHU 9 South)
New York Presbyterian â€” Lower Manhattan Hospital, 170 William Street, New York, NY 10038
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at 6:33 a.m. on August 10, 2019.
Medical staff noted 'circumferential bruising around the neck' and 'posterior mottling' upon finding Epstein, consistent with hanging/asphyxiation.
Epstein was pronounced deceased at New York Presbyterian Hospital at 7:36 a.m. on August 10, 2019.
A Bureau of Prisons lieutenant instructed escorting staff 'not to speak to anyone and or the media' regarding the situation and to direct inquiries to the Public Relations Officer.
The FBI and USMS were notified of the incident, and the institution was locked down.
